sen.j: 一般に「廃仏毀釈」と言えば、日本において明治維新後に成立した新政府が慶応4年3月13日 (旧暦)（1868年4月5日）に発した太政官布告「神仏分離令」、明治3年1月3日 (旧暦)（1870年2月3日）に出された詔書「大教宣布」など神道国教・祭政一致の政策によって引き起こされた仏教施設の破壊などを指す。
sen.e: When referred to as "Haibutsu-kishaku", it generally means the destruction of Buddhist facilities caused by the policy of Shinto kokkyo (establishing Shinto as a state religion) and Saisei icchi (uniting Shinto and politics), which the new Japanese government that was established after Meiji Restoration adopted by issuing the edict of Dajokan (the Grand Council of State) dated April 5, 1868 called "Shinbutsu Bunrirei (Ordinance distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism)" as well as the Imperial edict dated on February 3, 1870 called "Taikyo Senbu (Establishment of Shinto)".

sen.j: 神仏分離令や大教宣布は決して仏教排斥を意図したものではなかったが、結果として廃仏毀釈運動（廃仏運動）とも呼ばれる民間の運動を引き起こしてしまった。
sen.e: Neither Shinbutsu Bunrirei nor Taikyo Senbu was issued with the aim of boycotting Buddhism, but they eventually gave rise to a civil movement called the Movement of Haibutsu kishaku (the Movement of Haibutsu).

sen.e: Because various actions were taken hastily, including, but not limitted to, the decision of enshrined deities, consolidation of temples, monks' conversion to Shinto priests, destruction of Buddhist statues and Buddhist tools, prohibition of Buddhist rites and compulsion of citizens' conversion to Shinto, this movement caused chaos in the society.
